question: Question 1-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following isotopes has the largest microscopic absorption cross-section for thermal neutrons?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1988, Sec 8.1
Incorrect. REF: Introduction to Nuclear Operation, Reed Burn, 1988, Sec 8.1
Correct

question: Question 2-04/20/2018 You're increasing reactor power on a steady +15 second period. How long will it take to increase power by a factor of five?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: ln (P/P_0) × period = time. ln(5) × 15 = 1.61 × 15 = 24 seconds
Correct
Incorrect. REF: ln (P/P_0) × period = time. ln(5) × 15 = 1.61 × 15 = 24 seconds
Incorrect. REF: ln (P/P_0) × period = time. ln(5) × 15 = 1.61 × 15 = 24 seconds

question: Question 3-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following conditions will require the control rod withdrawal to maintain constant power level after the following change?

answers.answer: a. Adding of a fuel experiment such as U-235 into the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1

answers.answer: b. Insertion of an experiment containing borated graphite.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: c. Decrease of pool water temperature.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1

answers.answer: d. Burnout of Xenon in the core.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 3.3.1

question: Question 5-04/20/2018 If the multiplication factor, k, is increased from 0.800 to 0.950, the amount of reactivity added is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.05, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25. At k=0.95, ρ =- 0.05/0.95 ρ = -0.053. The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197

Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.05, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25. At k=0.95, ρ =- 0.05/0.95 ρ = -0.053. The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197

Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Sec 3.3.3, page 3-21. In order to solve the question A.05, the applicant can use one of the following methods: At k=0.8; ρ = ∆Keff/Keff or ρ = Keff-1/Keff = -0.2/0.8 =-0.25. At k=0.95, ρ =- 0.05/0.95 ρ = -0.053. The difference between ρ is the answer ,i.e. -0.053-(-0.25)=0.197 ∆ ρ = ρ1 – ρ2 where ρ1 = Keff1-1/Keff1 and ρ2 = Keff2-1/Keff2. Substitute ρ1 and ρ2 with Keff1 and Keff2 into the equation above, the result is ∆ρ = keff1-keff2/(keff1 x keff2) = 0.95-0.8 /(0.8*0.95)=0.197
Correct

Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.2

question: Question 8-04/20/2018 The reactor is critical at 10 W. A rod is pulled to insert a positive reactivity of $0.18. Which ONE of the following will be the stable reactor period as a result of this reactivity insertion? Given beta effective = 0.007.

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reactivity added = $0.18 x .007 = 0.00126 τ = (β-ρ)/λeffρ = .007 - .00126 = 45.6 seconds (0.1) (.00126)
Correct
Incorrect. REF: Reactivity added = $0.18 x .007 = 0.00126 τ = (β-ρ)/λeffρ = .007 - .00126 = 45.6 seconds (0.1) (.00126)
Incorrect. REF: Reactivity added = $0.18 x .007 = 0.00126 τ = (β-ρ)/λeffρ = .007 - .00126 = 45.6 seconds (0.1) (.00126)

question: Question 9-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following is the MINIMUM amount of reactivity that makes the Reed College (finite) critical reactor to be a prompt critical reactor? This MINIMUM amount is equal to:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6
Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction of Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6
Correct

question: Question 10-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following best describes the likelihood of fission occurring in U-235 and U-238?

answers.answer: a. Neutron cross sections of U-235 and U-238 are independent from the neutron velocity.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.2

answers.answer: b. Neutron cross section of U-235 increases with increasing neutron energy, whereas neutron cross section of U-238 decreases with increasing neutron energy.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.2

answers.answer: c. Neutrons at low energy levels (eV) are more likely to cause fission with U-238 than neutrons at higher energy levels (MeV).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Section 3.2

answers.answer: d. Neutrons at low energy levels (eV) are more likely to cause fission with U-235 than neutrons at higher energy levels (MeV).
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 11-04/20/2018 Reactor A increases power from 10% to 30% with a period of 25 seconds. Reactor B increases power from 70% to 100% with a period of also 25 seconds. Compared to Reactor A, the time required for the power increase of Reactor B is:

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 3, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.43. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase of reactor B takes a shorter time.

answers.answer: b. exactly the same as A
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 3, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.43. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase of reactor B takes a shorter time.

Incorrect. REF: The power of reactor A increases by a factor of 3, while the power of reactor B increases by a factor of 1.43. Since the periods are the same (rate of change is the same), power increase of reactor B takes a shorter time.
Correct

Correct

question: Question 16-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following describes the term PROMPT JUMP?

answers.answer: a. A reactor is subcritical at negative 80-second period
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: b. A reactor has attained criticality on prompt neutrons alone
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: c. The instantaneous change in power level due to inserting a control rod
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1982, Page 4-21.

answers.answer: d. The instantaneous change in power level due to withdrawing a control rod
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 17-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following is a correct statement describing prompt and delayed neutrons? Prompt neutrons:

answers.answer: a. are released during U-238 interacts with fast neutrons, while delayed neutrons are released during U-235 interacts with thermal neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: b. account for less than 1% of the neutron population, while delayed neutrons account for the rest.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

answers.answer: c. are released during the fission process, while delayed neutrons are released from precursors.
answers.feedback: Correct

answers.answer: d. are the dominating factor in determining reactor period, while delayed neutrons have no effect on reactor period.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988

question: Question x-04/20/2018 What is the condition of the reactor when k = 1/1-β

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: LaMarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, Page 340-341 (1-β)k=1 manipulated reads k=1/(1-β)
Incorrect. REF: LaMarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, Page 340-341 (1-β)k=1 manipulated reads k=1/(1-β)
Incorrect. REF: LaMarsh, Introduction to Nuclear Engineering, Page 340-341 (1-β)k=1 manipulated reads k=1/(1-β)

question: Question 19-04/20/2018 Which ONE of the following conditions will INCREASE the shutdown margin of a reactor?

answers.answer: a. Lowering moderator temperature (assume negative temperature coefficient).
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Decreasing the reactivity worth in the core, it will increase the shutdown margin.

answers.answer: b. Insertion of a positive reactivity worth experiment.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Decreasing the reactivity worth in the core, it will increase the shutdown margin.

answers.answer: c. Burnout of a burnable poison.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Decreasing the reactivity worth in the core, it will increase the shutdown margin.
Correct

question: Question 20-04/20/2018 Select the dominant contributor for the prompt negative temperature coefficient in the TRIGA fuel.

answers.answer: a. As the fuel heats up the resonance absorption peaks broaden and increases the likelihood of neutron absorption in U-238
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: b. As the fuel heats up a rapid increase in moderator temperature occurs through conduction and convection heat transfer mechanisms which adds negative reactivity
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: c. As the fuel heats up fission product poisons (e.g., Xe) increase in concentration within the fuel matrix and add negative reactivity via neutron absorption
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: TRIGA Fuel Design

answers.answer: d. As the fuel heats up the oscillating hydrogen in the ZrH lattice imparts energy to a thermal neutron, thereby increasing its mean free path and probability of escape
answers.feedback: Correct
